hedline.hl1: Kohl Faces Criticism For Skipping U.N. Gala

block.p: Chancellor Helmut Kohl's absence from the United Nations 50th-anniversary observances this week has provoked some loud grumbling here, with several members of the German Parliament criticizing the Chancellor for choosing to stay home.
"Was it arrogance, error or simply indifference to the U.N. that kept you away from the celebrations?" Eberhard Brecht, of the opposition Social Democrats, asked Wednesday in Parliament.

Chancellor Helmut Kohl's absence from the United Nations 50th-anniversary observances this week has provoked some loud grumbling here, with several members of the German Parliament criticizing the Chancellor for choosing to stay home.
"Was it arrogance, error or simply indifference to the U.N. that kept you away from the celebrations?" Eberhard Brecht, of the opposition Social Democrats, asked Wednesday in Parliament.
Another opposition figure, Helmut Lippelt, said the Chancellor's absence reflected "a remarkable gap between the rhetoric and the reality of German policy toward the U.N."

After several such comments, Mr. Kohl took to the floor to defend himself. He said he had decided to stay away from New York because, like other world leaders, he would have been able to address the General Assembly for only five minutes.

He dismissed suggestions that he could have met with other world leaders at the United Nations. "I don't have to go to New York to speak with Yasir Arafat," he said, adding, "No one in Europe or anywhere else" backs the world body more than Germany. WORLD NEWS BRIEFS
